required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Abnormal Plantar Pressure in Patients With Diabetes
clinical_study.official_title: Prevention of Foot Injuries - Abnormal Distribution Patterns of Plantar Pressure in Patients With Diabetes and Its Connection to Peripheral Neuropathy, Gender, Age and BMI

brief_summary.textblock: The prevalence of abnormal plantar pressure distribution (APD) and its connection with various factors among patients with diabetes is not known. The purpose of this study was to evaluate the prevalence of the APD and its connection with selected factors among patients with diabetes.

detailed_description.textblock:
The abnormal plantar pressure distribution (APD) plays a key role in the formation of plantar calluses which are responsible for diabetic foot ulcer.
The knowledge of APD is necessary to plan proper prevention in the group of patients with diabetes mellitus (DM).
Medical records from previous patients' visits of non-ulcer patients with diabetes were retrospectively analysed. The relationship between APD, obtained during a pedobarographic test as a semi-quantitative assessment with colourful print analysis, and neuropathy, gender, age and BMI was searched.

primary_outcome.description: static pedobarographic test with semi-quantitative assessment: number of the patients with abnormal plantar pressure location based on a semi-quantitative method, as static barefoot pedobarographic records with colourful print analysis. The intensity of colour was proportional to the pressure received. Warm colours indicated the greatest pressure, while cold colours indicated the least plantar pressure (starting with red, then yellow, green, and blue)

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants With Positive Test for Neuropathy
secondary_outcome.description: Peripheral neuropathy is assessed with questions and clinical evaluation. A nurse asks the patient about stinging, numbness, tingling, or burning of the foot. Ten-gram monofilament and tuning fork (128 MHz) tests are administered. Monofilament is applied in 10 locations on the sole and one on the dorsal part of the foot for checking the loss of protective sensation. A positive monofilament test is considered to be the lack of sensation of tightness in at least 6 of 11 tested sites. The tuning fork is applied for vibration detection to both ankles, the first metatarsophalangeal joint, and the anterior aspect of the shin bone sites. A positive vibration test is considered to be no detection of vibration in three of four test sites.Two positive test results and typical symptoms of neuropathy are the basis for confirmation of peripheral symmetric sensory neuropathy (PSSN). The condition required for the occurrence of these disorders was symmetry.

arm_group.description: Data from medical records from : non-ulcer patients with DM (diabetes mellitus) from the Diabetic Foot Centre (DFC) in Wroclaw. As it is a retrospective analysis no intervention is planned.

intervention.intervention_name: retrospective observational study with no intervention

study_pop.textblock: Wroclaw (where the Diabetic Foot Centre exists) citizens who came spontaneously to be examined despite the absence of diabetic foot signs or symptoms

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- subjects with diabetes mellitus diagnosis
- citizens
- no previous foot ulceration and/or foot surgery
Exclusion Criteria:
- previous foot ulceration and/or foot surgery

facility.name: Department and Division of Medical Rehabilitation

responsible_party.investigator_title: MD, PhD; Head of the Department and Division of Medical Rehabilitation

patient_data.ipd_description: all collected individual participant data but without individual foot-print picture (mostly paper documentation) ; only the example of foot -print with explanation is available
patient_data.ipd_access_criteria: will be included in an article and/or as supplementary materials

participant_flow.recruitment_details: Recruitment period: between October 2009 and December 2010 Medical records were obtained from the Diabetic Foot Centre (DFC) in Wroclaw, Poland and covered a period of fifteen months of work.
participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: Patients without previous ulcerations or foot surgery were evaluated.

group.title: Patients With Diabetes
group.description: Data from medical records from : non-ulcer patients with DM (diabetes mellitus) from the Diabetic Foot Centre (DFC) in Wroclaw. As it is a retrospective analysis no intervention is planned. retrospective observational study with no intervention: no intervention

group.title: Patients With Diabetes
group.description: Data from medical records from : non-ulcer patients with DM (diabetes mellitus) from the Diabetic Foot Centre (DFC) in Wroclaw. As it is a retrospective analysis no intervention is planned. retrospective observational study with no intervention: no intervention

measure.title: Age
measure.description: Age- was calculated based on patients identification (ID) number (in Poland each ID number contains date of birth).

outcome.title: Abnormal Plantar Pressure Distribution
outcome.description: static pedobarographic test with semi-quantitative assessment: number of the patients with abnormal plantar pressure location based on a semi-quantitative method, as static barefoot pedobarographic records with colourful print analysis. The intensity of colour was proportional to the pressure received. Warm colours indicated the greatest pressure, while cold colours indicated the least plantar pressure (starting with red, then yellow, green, and blue)
outcome.population: Patients with diabetes mellitus but without active or past foot ulcer or surgical procedure within the feet. Abnormal plantar pressure distribution (APD) - means number of participants with symmetrical abnormal pressure distribution; No APD- without such kind a distribution.

group.title: Patients With Diabetes
group.description: Patients with diabetes from Diabetic Foot Centre

measure.title: Abnormal Plantar Pressure Distribution
measure.description: static pedobarographic test with semi-quantitative assessment: number of the patients with abnormal plantar pressure location based on a semi-quantitative method, as static barefoot pedobarographic records with colourful print analysis. The intensity of colour was proportional to the pressure received. Warm colours indicated the greatest pressure, while cold colours indicated the least plantar pressure (starting with red, then yellow, green, and blue)
measure.population: Patients with diabetes mellitus but without active or past foot ulcer or surgical procedure within the feet. Abnormal plantar pressure distribution (APD) - means number of participants with symmetrical abnormal pressure distribution; No APD- without such kind a distribution.

outcome.title: Number of Participants With Positive Test for Neuropathy
outcome.description: Peripheral neuropathy is assessed with questions and clinical evaluation. A nurse asks the patient about stinging, numbness, tingling, or burning of the foot. Ten-gram monofilament and tuning fork (128 MHz) tests are administered. Monofilament is applied in 10 locations on the sole and one on the dorsal part of the foot for checking the loss of protective sensation. A positive monofilament test is considered to be the lack of sensation of tightness in at least 6 of 11 tested sites. The tuning fork is applied for vibration detection to both ankles, the first metatarsophalangeal joint, and the anterior aspect of the shin bone sites. A positive vibration test is considered to be no detection of vibration in three of four test sites.Two positive test results and typical symptoms of neuropathy are the basis for confirmation of peripheral symmetric sensory neuropathy (PSSN). The condition required for the occurrence of these disorders was symmetry.
outcome.population: Patients with DM, without active or past ulcer or surgery within the feet.The data was collected, grouped and analyzed separately for: PSSN, motor neuropathy (MN): MN-Calluses and MN-Feet deformity. One patient can developed PSSN and calluses and feet deformity (and thus his/her result was incorporated into each arm) or one of these variables.

group.title: Patients With Diabetes
group.description: Patients with diabetes from Diabetes Foot Center (DFC)

measure.description: Peripheral neuropathy is assessed with questions and clinical evaluation. A nurse asks the patient about stinging, numbness, tingling, or burning of the foot. Ten-gram monofilament and tuning fork (128 MHz) tests are administered. Monofilament is applied in 10 locations on the sole and one on the dorsal part of the foot for checking the loss of protective sensation. A positive monofilament test is considered to be the lack of sensation of tightness in at least 6 of 11 tested sites. The tuning fork is applied for vibration detection to both ankles, the first metatarsophalangeal joint, and the anterior aspect of the shin bone sites. A positive vibration test is considered to be no detection of vibration in three of four test sites.Two positive test results and typical symptoms of neuropathy are the basis for confirmation of peripheral symmetric sensory neuropathy (PSSN). The condition required for the occurrence of these disorders was symmetry.
measure.population: Patients with DM, without active or past ulcer or surgery within the feet.The data was collected, grouped and analyzed separately for: PSSN, motor neuropathy (MN): MN-Calluses and MN-Feet deformity. One patient can developed PSSN and calluses and feet deformity (and thus his/her result was incorporated into each arm) or one of these variables.

outcome.title: BMI
outcome.population: Patients after BMI were assigned to one of two groups : BMI<35 kg/m2 or ≥35 kg/m2

measure.title: BMI
measure.population: Patients after BMI were assigned to one of two groups : BMI<35 kg/m2 or ≥35 kg/m2

reported_events.time_frame: Not applicable- observational, retrospective study with medical-records analysis.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: All Principal Investigators ARE employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.

clinical_results.limitations_and_caveats: Lack of the influence of a type and duration of diabetes mellitus.The neuropathy evaluation based on local recommendations. The semi-quantitative analysis of the pressure map; the retrospective nature of the study.
